dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The field is aflare with floodlights  - on one side is an office building  - on the other are hangars. The whole  field is filled with Chinese refugees  running around wildly. An Army transport  is in front of the office building,  motors going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing in the distance, probably several  miles away, the effect of a burning  city, which is Baskul. Over the shot  we hear the steady boom-boom of gunfire.  In the f.g., we see the silhouetted  figures of Chinese running away from  Baskul and toward the Camera, their  personal packs on their backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toward office building. Conway comes  out of the building, followed by a small  group of white people with frightened  faces. They have to fight their way  through a horde of milling Chinese.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway and group finally reach the  plane where Conway forces the white  people in. In this he is aided by his  brother, George, a young and vigorous  Englishman. The pilot sticks his head  out of the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, we can't take more than seven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway pulls a passenger out and gives  the pilot a signal to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'm sorry. There will be  another plane in a minute. All right  - go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Motors roar, and the plane starts to  move, scattering those of the Chinese  who were unfortunately too close to  the ship. Conway and George rush back  into the office building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are about thirty white refugees,  men, women and several children. They  all lift their panicky faces to Conway  and George as they enter. A barrage  of questions are flung at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there any more planes? Do you think  the bandits will come here? Please take  my wife next, Mr. Conway!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait! Everybody, wait! There are  plenty of planes coming. Now everybody  have patience. Everything will be all  right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to a back room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have nothing to worry about. Leave  everything to my brother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway enters to speak to operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir - with seven passengers aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking to them now, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway speaking. Is Colonel Marsh there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, I need more planes. I've still  about twenty people to get out. Where  are those planes you promised us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We sent everything we could find, Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They better get here soon or I can't  be responsibleВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob! I think I hear motors!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Colonel, wait a minute, they may be  here now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say George, get down on that field and  guide those planes in when they get  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be sure that none of the natives  get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks - and take care of that liver  of yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, get ready everybody. The  planes are here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people crowd around him pleading  for priority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One at a time. Children first. Where  are they? Come on now, and stand over  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman pushes some children forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (directing people aside - pulling out  an old lady)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you come - right over here - and  you, and youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A girl slouched in a corner. We meet  Gloria Stone, a surly, wan-looking prostitute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better take some of those squealing  men with you first. They might faint  on you. I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something of a smile crosses his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, a terrific explosion is heard  in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lights go out. Everybody starts  screaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! Don't lose your heads now - I'll  see what it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway rushing out, meets George coming  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The power house - they've blown it up!  The planes can't land without lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! We'll burn the hangar. That  will make light for them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a lantern and dashes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they run through the screaming mob  toward the hangar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is filled with Chinese refugees clinging  to their household goods. Conway and  George enter. Conway speaks to them  in Chinese, ordering them out. Some  hesitate, and they have to push the  terror-stricken waiting coolies out.  When they have all left, Conway opens  the spigots of several gasoline tanks,  waits for the fuel to spill on the ground,  then tosses a lantern on the fuel, igniting  a blaze. At the same moment, he and  George dash for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway and George rush out of hangar.  When they are at a fairly safe distance,  the building bursts into flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against a background of the burning  hangar, a plane is just leaving the  ground, as another one is landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We go on to the next plane. Bring out  any people that are left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the burning city of  Baskul in the distance. We see the bandits  coming, flashing bayonets, in pursuit  of screaming refugees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21. MED. SHOT FRONT OF OFFICE BUILDING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway emerges, followed by Gloria,  and an American, Barnard. CAMERA FOLLOWS  THEM to the ship just as the pilot,  Fenner, is climbing down from cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Conway. Having a little trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never mind me. Get this gadget off  the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, these are all that are left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Conway and others approach, George  helps Gloria Stone up, while Conway  faces the mob, punching at those who  try to wedge their way forward. Finally  one of them manages to get his foot  on the step, and Conway pushes him violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who staggers back and falls, sprawling.  As he hits the ground, he yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't leave me here, you blighter.[2]  I'm a British subject!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway looks his surprise and lifts  him off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glaring off toward Conway, picks up  a board and starts toward Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 26. MED. CLOSE SHOT ENTRANCE TO SHIP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George emerges in time to see the Chinese  lift the board and about to clout Conway  on the head. George moves quickly, puts  out his left hand, wards off the blow  and with his right he punches the Chinese,  who reels out of the scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shadowy figure materializes in the  cockpit, and clubs Fenner from behind.  He shoves Fenner aside and takes his  place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway pushes George up and starts to  mount himself. He looks off - and what  he sees startles him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what Conway sees. Several trucks  loaded with bandits - in makeshift uniforms  - come tearing up the road - come to  a stop. Some fire toward plane - others  are setting up machine guns. Droves  of refugees scramble to cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already present are Barnard, an American;  Gloria Stone, the prostitute; and Lovett,  whom we saw dressed as a Chinese. Conway  slams the door shut - looks off - then  cries:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get down on the floor, everybody. Go  ahead, Fenner!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all fall on their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the new pilot setting the controls  and lifting the plane into flight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plane swings around - taxies  crazily - and leaves the ground, accompanied  by gunfire of the bandits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The occupants are still on the floor.  Conway rises and glances out of a window,  warily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I guess we're out of range.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are murmurs of "Yes" - "I'm all  right" - as they raise themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway starts for the back seat and  suddenly sees Lovett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why aren't you registered through our  office?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would serve you right if you were  left behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could I know that a war was going  to break out right over my head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right over my head. Oh, my word! I tell  you, those Chinese were pouncing on  me from every direction. I had to get  into these ridiculous clothes in order  to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hiding? Oh, no. Hunting - I was in the  interior - hunting fossils. This morning  I looked up suddenlyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know - and a war broke out right over  your head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next time you're in wild country  like this, keep in touch with the British  Consul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aha - very good, Freshie.[3] Very good.  You'd better put his name on the list  and make out a report later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He proceeds to the back seat. Barnard,  the American, who is in front of Lovett,  leans over toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon, brother. What did  you say you were hunting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett produces a small box clutched  under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have here a discovery that will startle  the world. It's the vertebrae from the  lumbar of a Megatherium,[4] found in  Asia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what do you know about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I get home I shall probably be  knighted for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knighted! You don't say. Do you mind  if I take a look at it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lifts the lid and Barnard peeks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrapped carefully in absorbent cotton  is something that resembles a dry chicken  bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard reaches for the box, but Lovett  pulls it away from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the only thing I was able to  save when those heathens surrounded  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he is allowed to take it out and examine  it - unimpressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, from this vertebrae I shall  be able to reconstruct the entire skeleton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, you expect to be knighted  for finding that soupbone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was the vertebrae of a Megatherium  - found in Asia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I remember. You said that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Henry Derwent was knighted, and  he never got beyond the mesozoic era.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett glares at him resentfully, and  snaps the lid shut on his box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I'm talking to you.  I don't know you. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria sits slumped in her seat, looking  glumly out. Barnard glances at her curiously.  Finally he makes a friendly overture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria turns her head, surveys Barnard  coldly, and without responding, turns  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, will you have a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, you're an American, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, listen - will you go and annoy  the rest of your playmates? Let me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shrugs his shoulders and slides back  into his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is silent for a moment. Conway is  writing on a small pad - which he rests  on an uplifted knee. George is rummaging  through a closet - rear of the cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway still writes, undisturbed. George  reaches into the closet and emerges  with a bottle of whiskey. His face lights  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just this once, Bob. I feel like celebrating.  Just think of it, Bob - a cruiser sent  to Shanghai just to take you back to  England. You know what it means.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are. Don't bother about those  cables now. I want you to drink with  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I give you Robert Conway  - England's new Foreign Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway watches him, amused. George gulps  down his drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (after a slight hesitation - downing  his drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How I'm going to bask in reflected glory!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People are going to point to me and  say, "There goes George Conway - brother  of the Foreign Secretary."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk nonsense. Give me the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway takes the bottle from him and  pours himself a second drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why they're sending for you,  Bob. With all these foreign entanglements,  it was bound to happen. They need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, with a poured drink in hand,  laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, you can laugh if you want  to. But who else can they get? Who else  is there in all of England half the  fighter, half the diplomat, who

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: has half your knowledge of the foreign  situation? They can't stop you now,  Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway moodily pours himself a third.  He downs the drink as we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find Conway, asleep in his seat,  his head on his hands. George approaches  and tenderly spreads a jacket over his  shoulders. Conway stirs, opens an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Freshie. Did you make that report  out yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you say we saved ninety white people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurray for us. Did you say that we left  ten thousand natives down there to be  annihilated? No, you wouldn't say that.  They don't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better try to get some sleep,  Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you wait until I'm Foreign Secretary.  Can't you just see me, Freshie, with  all those other shrewd, little Foreign  Secretaries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, the trick is to see who can  out-talk the other. Everybody wants  something for nothing, and if you can't  get it with smooth talk, you send an  army in. I'm going to fool them, Freshie.  I'm not going to have an army. I'm going  to disband mine. I'm going to sink my  battleships - I'm going to destroy every  piece of warcraft. Then when the enemy  approaches we'll say, "Come in, gentlemen  - what can we do for you?" So then the  poor enemy soldiers will stop and think.  And what will they think, Freshie? They'll  think to themselves - "Something's wrong  here. We've been duped. This is not  according to form. These people seem  to be quite friendly, and why should  we shoot them?" Then they'll lay down  their arms. You see how simple the whole  thing is? Centuries of tradition kicked  right in the pantsВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—and I'll be slapped straight into the  nearest insane asylum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to pour himself another drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better not drink any more, Bob.  You're not talking sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway downs the drink, and then chuckles  cynically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, George. Nothing's going  to happen. I'll fall right into line.  I'll be the good little boy that everybody  wants me to be. I'll be the best little  Foreign Secretary we ever had, just  because I haven't the nerve to be anything  else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Oh, sure, Freshie. Good thing,  sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grunts and squirms. George tucks  him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever notice the sunrise in China,  George? Ah, you should. It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets settled. George relaxes and,  leaning back, shuts his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is quiet. All are asleep. CAMERA  MOVES FORWARD SLOWLY until it reaches  the glass panel leading to the cockpit.  The pilot's face turns. Instead of Fenner  we see a strange, Mongolian face - with  sharp, piercing eyes. A half-smile plays  across his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Flying at high speed against a moonlit  sky. We stay on the shot until it vanishes,  a mere speck, over the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The morning sun peeks over a mountain  top. From the same direction, as if  arriving with the sun, the ship looms  up, and comes roaring toward us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All are asleep except Lovett, who fidgets  on his seat. Then Barnard stirs - opens  his eyes - and stretches. As he does  so, he sees that Lovett is awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't care for 'sister' last night,  and I don't like 'Lovey' this morning.  My name is Lovett - Alexander, P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's a good morning, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm never conversational before I coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard glances out of the window, looks  around outside thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Is it a good morning?  Say, we're supposed to be travelling  east, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it looks to me as if we're travelling  west.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any child knows how to tell direction.  Any child. I don't care where the child  is - in the air, on the earth, or in  the sea. If you face the rising sun,  your right hand is the north, and your  left hand is the southВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always get it twisted because I'm  left-handed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you just reverse it. Your left  hand isВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tries to explain - gets confused and  irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make what 'hand'  you are? The north is the north!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. All I know is - the sun rises  in the east, and we're going away from  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sulks by himself, looks around  - locates the sun in back of him - smiles  - satisfied he's right, throws a condescending  glance over at Barnard - then suddenly  his face clouds - the whole thing dawns  on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my word - of course - yes. Boy!  Boy, we're travelling in the wrong direction!  Wake up! We're going in the wrong direction!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't you arrange to make a little  less noise?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tell you, we're going west, and Shanghai  is east of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be quiet! Fenner's the best pilot in  China. He knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He might have lost his way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. That's what I told them last  night. You can't expect a man to sail  around in the dark.[5]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During this George has been looking  around - he rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Calm yourself.  I'll talk to Fenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to panel leading to cockpit,  CAMERA FOLLOWING HIM. When he gets there  he knocks on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George knocks again. From the cockpit  side - the small shade suddenly snaps  up - and George finds himself staring  into the face of the mysterious pilot.  He takes an instinctive step backward.  The pilot turns his head. CAMERA ANGLE  WIDENS as George keeps backing up until  he gets to Conway. George turns to Conway  and shakes his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway stirs in his sleep, slowly opens  his eyes, yawns and stretches. Throughout  it, George speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up! Something's happened! It isn't  Fenner in the cockpit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway looks at him, glances off toward  the others, and back at George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bloke up there looks a Chinese,  or a Mongolian, or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're nowhere near Shanghai. We're going  in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This interests Conway and he looks out  of the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're over the desert. That's funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then rising, he crosses to cockpit.  The others watch him expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway pounds on the panel. The face  of the pilot appears in sight. Conway  tries to ask him something in Chinese.  The pilot glares at them for a second,  then a gun is shoved out at them. Instinctively  they back away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice puss to meet in a dark alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship lurches - and they are thrown  off balance. The panel has been snapped  shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. And who is he ? How'd he get there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you suppose we stopped someplace  during the night and changed pilots?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's not possible! If we had landed,  we all would have been awakened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. We never left the air. I  know - I didn't sleep the whole night  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That fellow got on at Baskul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he doing? Where's he taking us?  He may be a maniac for all we know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, who has disappeared during the  above, now returns, with a monkey wrench  in his hand. Conway stops him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, what are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to drag him out and force  him to tell us what his game is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll smash his face in. That's what  we'll do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can anyone here fly a plane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a general chorus of "noВ—not  I," etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway throws the monkey wrench into  a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we're in for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. He must have had some  purpose in taking the plane away from  Fenner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he lands, we'll find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean to tell me you're not going  to do anything until we land?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you - youВ— Look here - he may dash  us to pieces!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might afford you a great deal of  relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now gentlemen, I'm going back to sleep.  Oh, and I was having such a peaceful  dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As soon as he lands, let me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuts his eyes and leans back. The  others watch him for a second - and  wander back to their seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria is apparently indifferent to  their predicament. As Barnard watches  her, a little bitter smile plays around  her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares out of the window and is suddenly  startled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the plane with its nose turned downward  in a sharp descent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're heading down! We're going to land!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone looks out. George rushes to  Conway and nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, we're coming to a village!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway sits up and looks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plane starting toward ground. All we  can see are mountain tops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all stare out of the windows. Conway  peers intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From angle in cabin of plane. Through  the window, directly below we see a  large open space at the foot of the  hills. The plane is headed for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a swarm of strange-looking natives,  scantily attired, but bearing bayonets,  running toward the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of George and Conway, as the ship hits  the ground, bouncing and swaying perilously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the plane taxies across the uninhabited  space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway and George ready to get out.  As Conway turns to open the door, he  looks off and is startled by something  he sees. George follows his gaze, and  a bewildered expression comes into his  eyes, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting through door. The strange-looking  natives have surrounded the plane and  are closing in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway and George both instinctively  wheel around toward the opposite side.  But from that direction too, a horde  of natives dash toward them. Conway  hesitates a second, and like a flash  springs for the door. But he stops again,  as he opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To include door of plane. Conway finds  himself staring into the threatening  mouths of half a dozen rifles, and quickly  shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I can't get the dialect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the pilot and several natives  in single file as they come toward the  plane, buckets in hand. In b.g., one  of them lowers a bucket into a well  in the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look - they're loading up with gasoline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gas is being loaded. Natives on  horseback dash back and forth shouting  and signalling. Camels can be glimpsed  among the horses. There is tremendous  disorder and commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship leaves the ground. The natives  stand around, curiously watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway is pacing. The occupants sit  by their open windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imagine having all that fuel there,  waiting for us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, something tells me our journey  is just beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ask me, we're heading straight  for those mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the plane against the sky. In  the b.g., there is nothing but snow-covered  mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: A sign reading "Shanghai Municipal  Airport."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Chinese officer is on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Douglas plane[6] from Baskul with  Conway and four others aboard are missing.  Unreported between here and Baskul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A switchboard operator besieged by calls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Newspapers being run off a press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a high official of the British Foreign  Office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make it very emphatic that His Majesty's  Government will hold the Chinese government  and all Chinese governors of Chinese  provinces responsible for the complete  safety of Robert Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal other  foreign department officials and functionaries  arriving in the midst of his speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fantastic. The plane couldn't disappear  into thin air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And cable Lord Gainsford at Shanghai.  Leave no stone unturned to find Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get a postponement of the Far  East conference. We can't afford to  meet those nations without Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The occupants are hunched up in the  corner of their seats. What little clothes  they have, and what few blankets, are  bundled around them. All the windows  are shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is silence for a moment before  Barnard speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be kidnapping. They wouldn't  be taking us so far on such a dangerous  trip. No sense to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one responds to his speculation and  he lapses into silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To include George, Conway and Lovett.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you make of it, Bob? You must  have some idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? I give it up. But this not knowing  where you're going is exciting anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Conway, for a man who is supposed  to be a leader, your do-nothing attitude  is very disappointing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want him to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm a paleontologist,  not a Foreign Secretary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett slips back into his corner and  pulls his coat over his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Registering above 10,000 feet. We STAY  on it as it climbs and climbs to 15,000  feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 71. Showing the plane high over mountain  peaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against a moonlit sky, we see a lone  speck - the plane as it flies high above  the mountains. It appears to be traveling  through endless space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The atmosphere is pervaded with a feeling  of utter futility. The occupants are  still slumped in the corners of their  seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria has a fit of coughing. She grabs  her throat - as she gasps for breath.  Barnard, himself feeble and exhausted,  glances over at her sympathetically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Including Lovett, George, and Conway.  Lovett sits with his chin helplessly  on his chest, his mouth ludicrously  open, his eyes popping. George, his  teeth clenched, struggles against a  desire to sob. Conway looks at him feelingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway's eyes never leave George, who  finally unable to control himself, emits  a sob - and rather ashamed, slaps his  hand over his mouth and turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not knowing that's so awful, Bob.  Not knowing where you're going, or why,  or what's waiting when you get there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, with an effort, stifles another  outbreak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At 20,000 feet - and while we stay on  it - keeps mounting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deathly silence. Gloria has her hands  to her ears, rocking in pain. Suddenly  her voice rents the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh! Oh! I can't stand it any longer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps up and moves about frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take us down! I can't stand this pain  any longer! Let me out of here I say!  I can't stand it any longer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She runs to one of the ship's doors  and pounds on it with her fist, then  tries to shove it open. A blast of frigid  air throws her back. George and Conway  manage to pry her off and pull her away.  Sobbing pitifully, she lets Conway steer  her back to her seat, where she bundles  up in torturous pain. For a moment nothing  is heard but her stifled moans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unexpectedly the cockpit panel opens,  and the pilot tosses something out in  Gloria's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now take it with your teeth. That's  right - bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, now. Come on now. That's right.  Now, bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the plane at twilight, fading into  deepest night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the cabin at night, everyone frozen  in despair. All of a sudden there is  a loud, sputtering noise from the outside.  They all react - listen for a moment  - until the noise dies completely. Now  nothing is heard - not even the motor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have run out of fuel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship sways several seconds and finally  rights itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of what they see from plane. Vast snow-covered  mountain peaks, with no sign of a stretch  big enough to land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The plane sways perilously in the cross  wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all silent - waiting prayerfully.  Conway turns to the others - his voice  electric with authority.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George - everybody - better get back  towards the tail! He may nose her over.  Into the corner, quick! George - cushions,  blankets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the plane nearing the ground,  sailing over some smaller hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Conway in front of them, the others  are crouching in the corner. There are  ad-libs of fearful assurances while  they hand around cushions and blankets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as the ship hits the ground for  the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The occupants brace themselves for the  jolt. The ship hits and bounces several  times and finally stops. Its nose seems  to bury itself in the ground. The people  are lifted high into the air where they  remain, suspended for a few seconds,  terror-stricken. Then, accompanied by  grinding, crackling sounds, the ship  flops back and falls on its side. For  a moment there is stark silence - while  the people do not stir. A look of relief  spreads over their faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers offer dazed replies:  "Okay - yeah - I think so." Meanwhile,  Conway has opened the door. A swirling  mass of snow greets them, so that they  have to force their way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Conway fight their way down  from the plane in the blinding snow.  George quickly runs around to the other  side. Conway crosses to the cockpit,  and clambers aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lit only by the dashboard light. Conway  sticks his head in from the outside.  His eyes which have been flashing with  determination suddenly sober. CAMERA  PANS OVER to pilot, who is slumped over,  his chin resting on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George pops into view on the opposite  side, just as Conway has found the pilot's  gun beside him on the seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? Has he fainted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway hops up beside the pilot. George  follows suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here George, take the gun. Hold the  lights. I'm going to search him before  he comes to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He resumes his search enthusiastically.  Suddenly he stops. The utter limpness  of the pilot's body gives him pause.  He lifts up his chin, stares into his  face - pulls up his eyelid and then  places a hand over his heart. He turns  slowly toward George, who has been watching  his brother intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must have happened the moment he  hit the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a look at this map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway holds the map under the dashboard  light. He studies it painstakingly,  and his tense expression changes to  one of deep concern. George's eyes are  glued on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where we were this morning. He  had it marked. Right on the border of  Tibet. Here's where civilization ends.  We must be a thousand miles beyond it  - just a blank on the map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It means we're in unexplored country  - country nobody ever reached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stares at him, wide-eyed, the  gravity of their situation slowly penetrating  his terrorized mind. Conway's thoughts  are interrupted by a knock on the panel,  and he looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 92. MED. CLOSE SHOT THROUGH GLASS PANEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the faces of Barnard and the  others. We hear their voices inquiring  - "Hey, Conway, what's happening?" -  "What's up?" - "Where are we?" - "What'd  you find out?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, our chances of getting out of  this are pretty slim. But it's up to  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't have three hysterical people  on our hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the cabin through the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway enters, he is met by a volley  of questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you say? What'd you find out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything's all right. The pilot won't  trouble us any more. He's - he's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is met by a series of exclamations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's nothing we can do until  the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking in George as he enters from cockpit.  His terror-stricken eyes look dully  before him. He stops in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The storm will probably die down by  then. My suggestion is that we better  all try and get a good night's rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the shoulders of Gloria, Barnard  and Lovett as they face Conway, who  sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell them the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all wheel around and face George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you tell them we're a million  miles from civilization, without a chance  of getting out of here alive? It's slow  starvation - that's what it is. It's  a slow, horrible death!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the significance of this outburst  finally sinks into the chaotic minds  of his listeners, they turn to Conway  hopefully, certain he will refute it.  But Conway looks beyond them at George.  From his noncommittal silence, they  realize that George's statement is the  truth. They slip into their seats. The  place is heavy with a fatalistic silence.  George slowly crosses to his seat near  Conway, avoiding his accusing eyes.  Suddenly the air is rent with harsh,  bitter laughter from Gloria. They all  look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's perfect! Just perfect!  What a kick I'm going to get out of  this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She emits another outburst of semi-hysterical  laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Gloria. The bitterness of a  lifetime in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year ago a doctor gave me six months  to live. That was a year ago! I'm already  six months to the good. I'm on velvet.[7]  I haven't got a thing to loseВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you! - you, the noble animals of  the human race, what a kick I'm going  to get out of watching you squirm for  a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flops into her seat and buries her  head in her hands. For quite a while  all we hear are her stifled sobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George throws sidelong glances at his  brother, feeling his guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting from front of plane, taking  in entire cabin. The only sound that  comes in on the tragic quiet is the  low moaning of the wind outside. A feeling  of doom has descended upon the five  people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward the mountains which  seem to imprison the valley below. The  snowstorm, treacherous in its fury,  seems to threaten the valley with complete  obliteration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the plane, tilted over on its side.  It is fully covered with snow. CAMERA  PANS UP TO LOVETT AND BARNARD, shivering  in their blankets as they pace worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Conway are missing. Lovett  turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've been gone for three hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others appear disinterested in this  observation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left us here to rot. That's what they've  done. Heroes of the newspapers!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, all right. Keep quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett sees something through the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104. MEDIUM SHOT - THROUGH WINDOW OF  PLANE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George and Conway are seen walking briskly  toward the plane, their few clothes  a scant protection against the biting  wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others quickly glance up, just as  Conway and George clamber aboard. Conway  has a serious mien, but George is full  of vigor and enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He holds out his hat which he has been  carrying, bottom side up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard and Lovett rush to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No chance of our starving now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When they see the contents of his hat,  their faces fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mountain grass. It's good, too. Here,  have some. I've read of people lasting  thirty days on this stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They grab handfuls. He goes on:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, my brother and I have worked  out a plan. If we use our heads, we  should be able to keep alive for weeks,  until he gets back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't know. But he's starting out  right away in the direction of India.  Sooner or later he's bound to run into  somebody - a tribe or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throughout the previous scene he has  been busily occupied making preparations.  Out of the baggage hold he has brought  some blankets and rope and has been  wrapping his feet in them. As George  speaks, he looks up and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now here's the idea. We found a cave  over by that small hill. After we bury  the pilot, we're moving in. We can have  a fire there. I shouldn't be surprised  to see Bob back within a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway's smile dies on his face. We  get a feeling he is attempting a futile  journey, and is fully aware of it. He  resumes the roping of his feet - his  movements mechanical.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard and Lovett all attention as  George speaks. Gloria, off to one side,  has her eyes peeled on Conway intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't got a Chinaman's chance[8]  of getting out of this country alive,  and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard peers out the plane window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look up and glance out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their angle. In the distance, just  appearing over the top of a hill, we  see a caravan of natives approaching.  They are not close enough to distinguish  who or what they are, but that they  are human beings is apparent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway takes in the unbelievable sight.  We hear the exultant exclamations of  the others. Barnard and Lovett start  out of the plane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they? Do you see them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where George, Lovett and Barnard wait,  a trifle awe-stricken. Conway joins  them. Gloria has stayed inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The approach of the caravan from the  viewpoint of the group. It comprises  some twenty Tibetans, attired in sheepskins,  fur, hats and boots. Somewhere in the  middle of the single file is Chang,  an elderly Chinese. Chang steps forward  as their leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway leaves his group and meets  the oncoming party. He approaches Chang  and bowing courteously, greets him in  Chinese. Chang turns his head slowly  and speaks in perfect Oxfordian English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am from a nearby Lamasery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've no idea, sir, how unexpected  and very welcome you are. My friends  and I - and the lady in the plane -  left Baskul night before last for Shanghai,  but we suddenly found ourselves travelling  in the opposite directionВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the mercy of a mad pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be eternally grateful if youВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have had a heart attack, or  perhaps the fumes. When the plane landed  he was dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just going to bury him when  you came along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang turns to some of his men and issues  an order in a foreign tongue, obviously  instructions to take care of the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, if you will be good enough to direct  us to your LamaseryВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall consider it an honor to accompany  you and your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He issues a command to his men and turns  to Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will need suitable clothes for the  journey. It is not particularly far,  but quite difficult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several men have hopped into the scene  while he has been speaking. They come  forward with boots - sheepskins - fur  caps, etc. As they start to get into  these new clothes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the caravan starts its journey back  up the hill. All five people are now  attired in their newly acquired outfit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing the party on various stages  of what looks like a humanly impossible  journey. We see them first climbing  - then across long vastnesses of flat  land. Each succeeding time we see them,  their feet drag more wearily. Their  breathing becomes more difficult. These  pictures finally

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway up a mountainside. The procession  is just starting around a hairpin curve.  They are forced to travel on a narrow  ledge overlooking a deep ravine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 120. CLOSE SHOT - LOVETT, BARNARD AND  GLORIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they cling against the rocky sides  and glance apprehensively down into  the abyss below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close by to Barnard. Gloria's face is  wan and haggard. Every upward move seems  to require a Herculean effort. She stops  and has a fit of coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the snake-like moving party. They  have reached quite a height although  the peak of the mountain they are ascending  towers high above them. The cutting  wind moans treacherously as it caroms  off the mountainside. A heavy mist envelops  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the snake-like line approaches a  narrow, treacherous footbridge and makes  a slow, difficult crossing in heavy  weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the group. They round a curve and  come upon a narrow crevice which opens  up into a passageway. One by one they  step through, assisted by the natives.  On the other side, they sigh relievedly.  Oddly, the wind has stopped, the chill  has lessened. They look up to inspect  their surroundings and a startled look  comes into their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Conway as he glances casually around.  What he sees leaves him transfixed.  He stares unbelievingly before him for  a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sight that is both magnificent and  incredible. The eye-filling horizon  before them throws out a softness and  a warmth that is breathless. On the  left is a group of colored pavilions  that seem as if suspended on the mountainside.  Down below, in the hazy distance, is  a valley which gives one the impression  of a huge tapestry, superb in its blending  of soft colors. In every direction,  wherever one might gaze, there is a  feast of strange and heavenly beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway's group and Chang. Chang smiles  as he watches their astonished faces.  Conway turns from the rare magnificence  of Shangri-La, unhampered by the wind  and storm they had just encountered,  and looks backward, in the direction  from which they came to assure himself  he is the victim of a nightmare. Chang,  watching him, answers him before he  can express his astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, we are sheltered by mountains  on every side. A strange phenomena for  which we are very grateful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the group approaches the beautiful  and peaceful Shangri-La.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the foot of a wide marble stairway  as the caravan stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the group, as they look around and  feast their eyes on the grandeur of  the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing around at his picturesque surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Conway's gaze. In an upper  window of a tower, their faces glued  to the pane, are two robed Lamas who  stare down curiously. CAMERA PANS OVER  to a very narrow terrace covered almost  completely by a floral arbor. In it  stands a statuesque woman of rare beauty.  She looks down at Conway intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he returns her gaze, impressed by  her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes still on the girl above. He  starts up the steps, staring at her,  then stumbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It suggests nothing we might expect  to see in this forsaken place. The motif  is neither Oriental nor religious -  but rather a delicately appointed room,  subdued in tones. At the moment, no  one is present except servants who silently  set the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Lovett peering worriedly toward dining  room door. He sees two servants who  flank the entrance and steps back hesitantly.  Barnard emerges from a room across the  hall, and Lovett beckons to him. Both  are attired in flowing robes not unlike  the one worn by Chang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Barnard, I do not like this place.  I definitely do not like this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me. Look at what they gave me  to wear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never looked better in your life.  As soon as our clothes are cleaned,  they're going to give them back to us,  Lovey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the doorway of the  dining room and halt. Two servants bow  and scrape and lead them in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something tells me this means food.  Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel as though I'm being made  ready for the executioner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the servants show Lovett and Barnard  to their places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? If this be execution, lead me  to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what they do with cattle just  before the slaughter. Fatten them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this moment Conway and George enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was refreshing! Oh, ho - the food  looks good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes something off the table and  nibbles at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some layout they got here. Did you get  a load of the rooms? You couldn't do  better at the Ritz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the conveniences for the condemned,  if you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway looks at him and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mind Lovey. He's got the misery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Conway, I don't like this place.  I don't like it. It's too mysterious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better than freezing to death down  below, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is in semi-darkness. The moon sends  a stream of light through the windows.  Outside we see the outline of towering  mountains. Spread across the bed - her  clothes unchanged - is the body of Gloria  - her face sunk deep in the pillows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria emits wracking coughs. After  a few moments - she sits up. Her cheeks  are wet - her hair disheveled - her  eyes bloodshot. We get an impression  of someone who has suffered for hours.  Finally, her coughing begins again -  and unable to stand it, she rises and  paces the floor - then she crosses to  the window and looks down, CAMERA PANNING  WITH HER - and into her eyes has come  a grim, determined expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is staring at the chasm below her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria continues to peer below - and  her coughing resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chang comes down the corridor - hears  the coughing and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang enters and watches Gloria for  a moment before speaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there something I can do for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria wheels around and glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've offered you some warm broth. I  thought perhaps-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get out of here! If any of you men  think you can come busting in here-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cannot finish as she is attacked  by a fit of coughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please calm yourself. You'll soon be  well if you do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need any advice from you! Get  me a doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but we have no doctors here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, you can help me! You can help  me jump over that cliff! I've been looking  and looking at the bottom of that mountain,  but I haven't got the nerve to jump!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't be looking at the bottom  of the mountain. Why don't you try looking  up at the top sometimes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't preach that cheap, second-hand  stuff to me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, beat it. Beat it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She flings herself across the bed, coughing  uncontrollably. Chang watches her sympathetically  for a few seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace be with you, my child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all look up as Chang enters. He  is escorted to his place at the head  of the table by two servants who stand  on either side of his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening. Good evening, my friends.  Oh no, no, no, please sit down. I hope  you found everything satisfactory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't have waited for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's remaining in her room. She isn't  feeling very well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now please go on without me. I eat very  little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting down the long table toward  Chang. He sits up straight - studying  them - as the others bend over their  food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meal is over. Conway sips from a  wine glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, there's certainly nothing wrong  with that meal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm glad you like it. It's made right  here in the valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that dinner is over, if you'll excuse  us, we're very anxious to discuss ways  and means of getting back home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing we want to do is to  cable the Foreign Office. All of England  is waiting to hear about my brother.  There's a cruiser at Shanghai ready  to take him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Well, as regards cabling, I'm  afraid I can't help. Unfortunately,  we have no wireless here. As a matter  of fact, we have no means of communication  with the outside world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stares at him suspiciously -  and then turns to Conway for his reaction  - but Conway is apparently disinterested  in the whole conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always been a source of deep regret,  but the mountains surrounding us have  made reception almost impossible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that event, we better make arrangements  to get some porters immediately. Some  means to get us back to civilization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you so certain you are away from  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far away as I ever want to be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, the porters will be very  well paid - that is, within reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that wouldn't help. You see,  we have no porters here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about those men we met this morning?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Those are our own people. They  never venture beyond the point where  you were met this morning. It is much  too hazardous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has remained quiet throughout the  scene, apparently interested only in  a paper in front of him, upon which  he has been writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT: What has been occupying Conway's  interest. It is a picture of Chang which  he has been listlessly drawing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you account for all this? Who  brought it in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all turn to Chang expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. There is a tribe of porters  some five hundred miles from here. That  is our only contact with the outside  world. Every now and again, depending  upon favorable weather of course, they  make the journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can we get in touch with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In that respect, you are exceedingly  fortunate. We are expecting a shipment  from them almost any time nowВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What exactly do you mean by "almost  any time now"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we've been expecting this particular  shipment for the past two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard and Lovett look shocked. George  starts to say something, but the words  choke in his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I can assure you, gentlemen, if  there is a prolonged delay, Shangri-La  will endeavor to make your stay as pleasant  as possible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now if you will excuse me, it is  getting late. I do hope you all sleep  well. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The servants move his chair back. Before  he goes, however, he turns to Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, a little surprised at the distinction  in his behalf, nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang exits. There is a hushed silence  following Chang's departure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I mean - mysterious. Mr.  Conway, I don't like that man. He's  too vague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't get much information out of  him, did we Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me we should be grateful.  We were in a bad mess this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all, this is quite pleasant. Why  not make ourselves comfortable until  the porters do arrive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he was speaking, the muted strains  of a violin float into the room. Conway  rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway crosses to a balcony door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I say. What do you say to  a rubber of bridge? I saw some cards  in the other room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, thanks. No, I'm too weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears onto the balcony. George  watches him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you Lovey? Come on. Let's  you and I play a game of honeymoon bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking? What about some double solitaire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, I'm very good at  double solitaire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett detests the pet names, but follows.  George thinks a moment - and crosses  to balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway is listening moodily to the soulful  music. George wanders in beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose all this comes under the heading  of adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've had plenty of it the last few  days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's far from over, from what I can  see. This place gives me the creeps,  hidden away like this - no contact with  civilization. Bob, you don't seem concerned  at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm feeling far too peaceful to  be concerned about anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm going to like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You talk as though you intend on staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something happened to me, when we arrived  here, George, that - well - did you  ever go to a totally strange place,  and feel certain that you've been there  before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a strange bird. No wonder Gainsford  calls you the man who always wanted  to see what was on the other side of  the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway's point of view, studying George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever want to see what's on  the other side of the hill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What could there be except just another  hill? In any event, I'm not curious.  At the moment, it seems to me we should  be concerned about getting home. I'd  give anything to be in London right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course you would. If ever we get  out of this place, the thing for you  to do is to take that job with Helen's  father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean if we should get out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's on your mind, Bob? You talk as  though we're going to have trouble getting  out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, I've been putting things together.  Do you notice the resemblance between  those natives and the pilot? And why  did those clothes materialize so conveniently  when they met us at the plane? Chang  himself just said that they never venture  beyond that point. What brought them  there? Unless it was to meet us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang's first question was about the  pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be some connection between  the plane and this place. They must  have deliberately brought us here. Why,  Bob? What reason could they have for  doing a thing like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what's on the other side of the  hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 154. LONG SHOT FROM A TOWER ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting over shoulders of two men in  f.g.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see a beautiful picture of the valley  below. There is a tranquility here that  is beatific. CAMERA PULLS BACK. The  two men are revealed as Conway and Chang.  They stand on a terrace of one of the  tower rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's three thousand feet, practically  straight down to the floor of the valley.  The Valley of the Blue Moon, as we call  it. There are over two thousand people  in the Valley besides those here in  Shangri-La.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who and what is Shangri-La? You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In time you will meet them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 155. CLOSE SHOT - THE TWO - FAVORING  CONWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches Chang's face searchingly,  then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For a man who talks a great deal, it's  amazing how unenlightening you can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some things, my dear Conway,  I deeply regret I may not discuss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that's the fourth time you've  said that today. You should have a record  made of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we go inside? I should so like  to show you some of our rare treasures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a spiral staircase. Looking surreptitiously  around, he backs his way up. CAMERA  FOLLOWS HIM as he reaches the top of  the landing. Here he stops and glances  around the corner down a corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS GEORGE as he peers into  several rooms searchingly. He finally  arrives at one and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters and looks around. It is  dimly lit and apparently unoccupied.  He crosses to a desk and picks up several  objects, scrutinizing them closely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 159. CLOSE SHOT OF THE GIRL, MARIA -  IN ALCOVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits, a tapestry board on her lap,  watching George with keen interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He opens a book and glances at its contents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George wheels around, startled, and  stares at her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tea will be served any moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her with grave speculation  for a long moment, then slowly moves  toward her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George still maintains a serious mien,  as their eyes meet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Maria. Won't you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a huge room. The walls are lined  with impressive tomes. Chang is showing  Conway around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway has just finished browsing through  one of the books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, what religion do you follow  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of surprise spreads over Conway's  face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To put it simply, I should say that  our general belief was in moderation.  We preach the virtue of avoiding excesses  of every kind, even includingВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find, in the Valley, it makes for  better happiness among the natives.  We rule with moderate strictness and  in return we are satisfied with moderate  obedience. As a result, our people are  moderately honest and moderately chaste  and somewhat more than moderately happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about law and order? You have no  soldiers or police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you deal with incorrigibles?  Criminals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, we have no crime here. What makes  a criminal? Lack, usually. Avariciousness,  envy, the desire to possess something  owned by another. There can be no crime  where there is a sufficiency of everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no disputes over women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only very rarely. You see, it would  not be considered good manners to take  a woman that another man wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suppose somebody wanted her so badly  that he didn't give a hang if it was  good manners or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, in that event, it would be good  manners on the part of the other man  to let him have her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 166. CLOSE SHOT - THE TWO - FAVORING  CONWAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's very convenient. I think I'd  like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised, my dear Conway,  how a little courtesy all around helps  to smooth out the most complicated problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang smiles. Conway scarcely hears  the last speech, for his attention has  been caught by the playing of a piano.  He stops to listen. Chang has walked  out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway locates the direction whence  the music comes, goes to a doorway where  he stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He realizes Conway did not follow him  and turns. When he sees Conway, his  face clouds - and he starts toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway watches someone through door  with grave interest. Chang enters scene  and follows his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From doorway. It is a spacious, high-ceilinged  room, oddly shaped, and except for a  piano, a harp and several chairs, is  otherwise sparsely furnished. At the  extreme end, the room is set off by  an alcove of stained glass extending  from the ceiling to the floor, where  it finishes with a deep window seat.  At the piano we see an old man - and  by his side is the girl Conway saw last  night. They finish playing and both  laugh heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway finds her laughter infectious  - and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 173. CLOSE SHOT - GIRL AND MAN AT PIANO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the midst of her laughter, the girl  sees Conway, off scene, and her face  sobers - self-consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang quickly takes Conway by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At some time in the future you will  have the pleasure of meeting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway turns for one last glimpse of  the girl, and then turns to Chang, looking  up at his face, puzzled and amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some man had better get ready to be  very courteous to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She continues to stare off toward the  door, her eyes alight with a keen interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 176. FOLLOW SHOT WITH CONWAY AND CHANG

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Mr. Chang, all these things - books,  instruments, sculpture - do you mean  to say they were all brought in over  those mountains by porters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Centuries! Where did you get the money  to pay for all those treasures?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course we have no money as you know  it. We do not buy or sell or seek personal  fortunes because, well, because there  is no uncertain future here for which  to accumulate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have arrived in a small room, where  they pause. Chang reaches into a bowl  of large nuts, cracks one, and hands  the nut to Conway. Then he does the  same for himself. During the following  scene, both are eating nuts from the  bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That would suit me perfectly. I'm always  broke. How did you pay for them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our Valley is very rich in a metal called  gold, which fortunately for us is valued  very highly in the outside world. So  we merely . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buy and - sell? No, no, pardon me, exchange  .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Gold for ideas. You know Mr.  Chang, there's something so simple and  naive about all of this that I suspect  there has been a shrewd, guiding intelligence  somewhere. Whose idea was it? How did  it all start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, my dear Conway, is the story of  a remarkable man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Belgian priest by the name of Father  Perrault, the first European to find  this place, and a very great man indeed.  He is responsible for everything you  see here. He built Shangri-La, taught  our natives, and began our collection  of art. In fact, Shangri-La is Father  Perrault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, let me see - way back in 1713, I  think it was, that Father Perrault stumbled  into the Valley, half frozen to death.  It was typical of the man that, one  leg being frozen, and of course there  being no doctors here, he amputated  the leg himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Oddly enough, later, when he had  learned to understand their language,  the natives told him he could have saved  his leg. It would have healed without  amputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they didn't actually mean that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes. They were very sincere about  it too. You see, a perfect body in perfect  health is the rule here. They've never  known anything different. So what was  true for them they thought would naturally  be true for anyone else living here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rather astonishingly so, yes. And particularly  so in the case of Father Perrault himself.  Do you know when he and the natives  were finished building Shangri-La, he  was 108 years old and still very active,  in spite of only having one leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no. Just a little bowled over, that's  all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me. I should have told you it  is quite common here to live to a very  ripe old age. Climate, diet, mountain  water, you might say. But we like to  believe it is the absence of struggle  in the way we live. In your countries,  on the other hand, how often do you  hear the expression, "He worried himself  to death?" or, "This thing or that killed  him?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And very true. Your lives are therefore,  as a rule, shorter, not so much by natural  death as by indirect suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all very fine if it works out.  A little amazing, of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, Mr. Conway, you surprise me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
