dialogues.text: I surprise you? Now that's news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, your amazement. I could have  understood it in any of your companions,  but you - who have dreamed and written  so much about better worlds. Or is it  that you fail to recognize one of your  own dreams when you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chang, if you don't mind, I think  I'll go on being amazed - in moderation,  of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then everything is quite all right,  isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a garden bench Gloria slumps languidly.  Suddenly we hear Barnard's voice, yelling.  Gloria quickly turns her back. Barnard  runs into scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, it's terrific! Terrific! I just  saw something that will make your hair  stand on end. You see those hills over  there? Gold! Gold! Popping right out  of them! Tons of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look, you keep this under your hat,  because if those other monkeys hear  about it, they'll declare themselves  in. But if I can mine that stuff, I'll  throw a bombshell into Wall Street.  Now look, I've got a plan - and if IВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria begins coughing heavily. Barnard  notices how pale and haggard she looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw say, honey, you aren't feeling well,  are you? Look, don't pay too much attention  to what those doctors tell you. I've  seen an awful lot of people fool them,  and I've got a hunch that this place  is going to be good for you. Honest,  I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on now. Come on. You be a good  kid, and snap out of it, and I'll cut  you in on the gold deal. Look, I'm going  up and make a deal with Chang - right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett enters warily, sits down at his  desk and begins to write in his journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE DIARY OF ALEXANDER P. LOVETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up, sees himself in a mirror  and gives a start. Then, chuckling to  himself reassuringly, he looks around  warily and continues to write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a bright, cheery morning. Conway  is drinking in the beauty of his surroundings.  He comes into the area where the horses  are stabled. Two men are busily grooming  the horses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you speak English, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to take a ride, Mr. Conway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, Conway is startled by the  sound of hoof-beats and, looking up,  is in time to see 'the girl' of the  previous sequence (Sondra) fly by him  on a horse - screaming delightedly.  As she passes him, she waves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think I will take that ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he rides off in pursuit of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Sondra successfully eluding  him - as he closes in on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 183. MED. LONG SHOT - BOTTOM OF A HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sondra whizzes by. As we stay on the  shot - Conway rides through in exciting  pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Sondra disappearing behind a  mountain waterfall. Conway dashes up,  but she is lost from sight. He wheels  around several times - and unable to  find her, looks puzzled. Finally, giving  up, he starts slowly back. After a few  moments he is startled by her laughter,  and glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his view - shooting upward. High  up - near the summit of the hill - we  see Sondra - waving and laughing. Then  she swings her horse around and disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he smiles - amused and interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she swims in a mountain stream, apparently  in the buff. From a distance, we see  her climb onto a rock to dry off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she shakes her shimmering hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has caught up to her tethered horse  and is skulking around trying to find  out where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squirrel, near to Sondra, chatters  excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She can apparently understand the squirrel's  warning. She hurries to dive back into  the water and swim to the other side.  She comes up, spots Conway and watches  him from hiding, behind some bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway has discovered her clothing and  is constructing a kind of scarecrow  on a bush out of them. As a crowning  touch, he adds a flower to the effigy,  his eyes twinkling at his little joke.  With one final glance over his shoulder,  he turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stifles her laughter as he vanishes  from view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett and Barnard are at the table  waiting for the others. Several servants  are in the b.g. George paces nervously  in front of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett and Barnard. Barnard nibbles  at something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bah! Fossils! Why? What for? Running  around digging up a lot of old bones!  You didn't dig yourself out of one of  those holes by any chance, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett is about to reply, when he realizes  he is being made fun of, and gives a  tentative chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway is coming down the corridor.  George comes out of door to dining room  and starts forward. Conway walks along  in a cheerful mood, singing as he goes,  a Cockney song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You seem gay. Did you find out anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they walk back toward dining room  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - I heard that if you want a man's  wife, she's yours, if he's got any manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens, Bob, we've been here two  weeks and we haven't found out a thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we haven't been murdered in our  beds yet, George, have we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid the porters are just a myth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we never will know why we're  here, or how long we're going to be  held prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have reached the door and start  into dining room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway and George enter, Barnard  calls to them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hurry up, you slow-pokes - I'm  starved!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (imitating Chang as he takes his chair)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please! Please! Do not wait for me!  I eat so very little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard laughs heartily. George, surily  silent, enters and drops in his seat.  At the same moment, Gloria comes into  the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men greet her, all rising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm certainly glad to see that  it's all finally organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, handsome. Dish it out, and make  it snappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he sits, he looks over at Gloria  and something in her face arrests him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's unkind. Doesn't Miss Stone always  look beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it! It's your make-up. You've  got none on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gloria busies herself with her soup,  self-consciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And say, honey, you look a million per  cent better. Wholesome, kind of - and  clean. You take a tip from me, and don't  you ever put that stuff on your face  again. Why, it's like hiding behind  a mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha, ha - who are you to be talking about  a mask? What do you mean? You've been  wearing a mask ever since we met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very strange, you know. You've  never told us anything about yourself.  Who are you, anyway? Why don't you take  your mask off for once!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, I will! I'll let my hair  down! Why not? It can't make any real  difference now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Lovey, were you ever chased by the  police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett is halted in his tracks - soup  spoon halfway up to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, it's no fun. When you fellas  picked me up at Baskul, they'd been  on my tail for a year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you ever hear of Chalmers Bryant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA PULLS BACK to include the others.  They look shocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the first one to make the connection)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is the only one unconcerned.  He is deeply absorbed in thought - his  food has remained untouched. Lovett  suddenly explodes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it. I knew I had a reason for  hating you! Sir, you're a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never stole anything from you , did  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have 500 shares of Bryant Utilities  that I bought with money that I saved  for 20 years teaching school, and now  I couldn't sell it for postage stamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's too bad. I got a half million  shares. My whole foundation! And now  look at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A colossal nerve you have sitting there  and talking about it so calmly - you,  the swindler of thousands of peopleВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, that's what makes the whole  thing so funny. A guy like me starts  out in life as a plumber - an ordinary,  everyday, slew-footed[12] plumber -  and by the use of a little brains, mind  you, he builds up a gigantic institution,  employs thousands of people, becomes  a great civic leader. And then the crash  comes - and overnight he's the biggest  crook the country ever had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are a thief, sir, and a swindler,  and I, for one, will be only too glad  to turn you over to the police when  we get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George can't stand it any longer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean - "when we get back"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sharpness of his voice startles  the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think we're ever going  to get back? You may not know it, but  you're all prisoners here. We were deliberately  kidnapped and brought here - and nobody  knows whyВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not content to be a prisoner.  I'm going to find out when we're going  to get out of this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make that Chinese talk if it's  the last thing I do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before anybody can realize what his  intentions are, he has bolted out of  the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George strides determinedly out into  the hall, yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly he sees a native servant and  his eyes pop insanely. CAMERA PANS WITH  HIM as he strides across to the servant  and grabs him by the shirt-front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? Where's Chang? Where is  he? Where's Chang, or I'll blow your  brains out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway has caught up with him and wrestles  him away from the servant, who stumbles  off in fright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, what do you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George pushes Conway away from him and  starts down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The servant, frightened by his voice,  turns suddenly and starts running. George  levels his revolver and sends a stream  of bullets after the fleeing servant,  who miraculously manages to skate around  a corner, unharmed. Conway runs into  scene, reaching George, and with a quick  flip of his left hand he smacks him  over his revolver arm - and with his  right, he punches him flush on the jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George reels for a moment and slumps  to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway pockets the gun and, bending  over George, a pained expression on  his face, starts to lift him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway brings George in, followed by  the others. He drapes him across his  bed. Conway stands by his side, looking  down at him, deeply concerned. After  a moment, Conway shakes him and George  awakens with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me up! Let me up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Barnard, Lovett and Gloria. Barnard  wanders over to Conway, who appears  lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say Conway, is it true about us being  kidnapped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say, is it true about us being kidnapped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway suddenly is aroused from his  reverie by someone he sees off scene.  He looks up alertly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind stepping in here for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Chang enters. He bows courteously  to the others, who stand in front of  George's bed. Conway shuts the door  and turns the key. He crosses to a door  leading to another room - and locks  this one, also. Chang watches him curiously.  The others, including George, who is  now alert, are puzzled and somewhat  impressed. Then Conway comes to Chang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang sits, his placidity unchanged.  Conway pulls up a chair in front of  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chang, you have been very kind to  us - and we appreciate it. But for some  reason we are being held prisoners here,  and we want to know why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 208. CLOSE SHOT - BARNARD, LOVETT AND  GLORIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway's voice continues, talking  to Chang:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I don't mind at all. I'm  enjoying every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my brother is not of the same opinion,  nor are the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time we were told what it's all  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want to know why we were kidnapped,  why we are being kept here, but most  important of all - do we get the porters,  and when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until we get this information, my dear  Mr. Chang, I am very much afraid we  cannot permit you to leave this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause while the eyes of all  are centered on Chang's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's very, very strange, but  when you saw me in the corridor, I was  actually on my way to you. I bring the  most amazing news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Lama wishes to see you, Mr.  Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Lama! Who in blazes is he?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I though you ran this joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Chang - High Lamas or Low Lamas,  do we get the porters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Lama is the only one from whom  any information can come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't believe him, Bob. He's just trying  to get out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a stall to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One moment. You say the High Lama is  the only one who can give us any information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he can arrange for the porters to  take us back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Lama arranges everything, Mr.  Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then he's the man I want to see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway unlocks the door. When he has  opened it, he turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better wait here until I get back. We'll  soon know where we stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CORRIDOR IN HIGH LAMA'S QUARTERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Conway and Chang. Chang walks in  a high state of expectancy. Conway is  grim. They climb a narrow spiral staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They proceed up the stairs until they  arrive at a large, impressively ornate  double door which seems to open automatically  the moment they approach. Chang remains  without. The moment Conway steps over  the threshold, the doors swing closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the doors swing shut. Conway turns  and realizes Chang is no longer with  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway stands still, glancing around  the room, which is lit so dimly that  nothing definite is distinguishable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To show what Conway sees. For the moment,  practically nothing. As his eyes become  adjusted to the darkness, he begins  to sense the architecture and furnishings  of the room. But as yet no sign of life.  SLOW PAN SHOT reveals it to be a dark-curtained  and low-ceilinged room, furnished rather  simply. Very sombre, indistinct tapestries  drape the back walls. While the CAMERA  FOLLOWS CONWAY'S GAZE, MOVING SLOWLY  AROUND, a voice is heard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA QUICKLY SWINGS OVER to the nethermost  corner of the room where, scarcely visible,  sits an old man of indeterminate age.  In the gloom only the outlines of his  pale and wrinkled face can be seen.  It yields an effect of a fading antique  portrait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares, motionless, at the eerie  vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway comes forward warily until he  stands within a few feet of the old  man, his eyes riveted upon him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit here, near me. I am an old man and  can do no one any harm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway, expressionless, sits down  opposite the High Lama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you have been comfortable at  Shangri-La, since your arrival.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally, I've enjoyed your community  very much. But my friends do not care  for this mystery. They are determined  to leave as soon asВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he has been speaking, his eyes  have been gradually taking in the details  of the old man. The CAMERA QUICKLY FOLLOWS  HIS GAZE - to crutches leaning against  the man's throne - then, looking down,  to his legs, one of which appears to  have been amputated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the man Chang told me about!  You're the first - who - two hundred  years agoВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not know it, but I've been an  admirer of yours for a great many years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, not of Conway the empire-builder  and public hero. I wanted to meet the  Conway who in one of his books, said,  "There are moments in every man's life  when he glimpses the eternal."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The quotation captures Conway's interest  - and his eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Conway seemed to belong here. In  fact, it was suggested that someone  be sent to bring him here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I be brought here? Who had that  brilliant idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the girl at the piano?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. She has read your books and has  a profound admiration for you, as have  we all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I have suspected that our  being here is no accident. Furthermore,  I have a feeling that we're never supposed  to leave. But that, for the moment,  doesn't concern me greatly. I'll meet  that when it comes. What particularly  interests me at present is, why was  I brought here? What possible use can  I be to an already thriving community?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need men like you here, to be sure  that our community will continue to  thrive. In return for which, Shangri-La  has much to give you. You are still,  by the world's standards, a youngish  man. Yet in the normal course of existence,  you can expect twenty or thirty years  of gradually diminishing activity. Here,  however, in Shangri-La, by our standards  your life has just begun, and may go  on and on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But to be candid, Father, a prolonged  future doesn't excite me. It would have  to have a point. I've sometimes doubted  whether life itself has any. And if  that is so, then long life must be even  more pointless. No, I'd need a much  more definite reason for going on and  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have reason. It is the entire meaning  and purpose of Shangri-La. It came to  me in a vision, long, long, ago. I saw  all the nations strengthening, not in  wisdom, but in the vulgar passions and  the will to destroy. I saw their machine  power multiply until a single weaponed  man might match a whole army. I foresaw  a time when man, exulting in the technique  of murder, would rage so hotly over  the world that every book, every treasure,  would be doomed to destruction. This  vision was so vivid and so moving that  I determined to gather together all  the things of beauty and culture that  I could and preserve them here against  the doom toward which the world is rushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at the world today! Is there anything  more pitiful? What madness there is,  what blindness, what unintelligent leadership!  A scurrying mass of bewildered humanity  crashing headlong against each other,  propelled by an orgy of greed and brutality.  The time must come, my friend, when  this orgy will spend itself, when brutality  and the lust for power must perish by  its own sword. Against that time is  why I avoided death and am here, and  why you were brought here. For when  that day comes, the world must begin  to look for a new life. And it is our  hope that they may find it here. For  here we shall be with their books

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and their music and a way of life based  on one simple rule: Be Kind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When that day comes, it is our hope  that the brotherly love of Shangri-La  will spread throughout the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my son, when the strong have devoured  each other, the Christian ethic may  at last be fulfilled, and the meek shall  inherit the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silence ensues during which Conway,  so engrossed is he in all he has just  heard, scarcely notices the Lama, who  has risen slowly and now stands before  him. The Lama reaches down and gently  touches him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway kisses the High Lama's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must come again, my son. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway slowly rises to his feet and  turns to leave scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 220. MED. CLOSE SHOT AT DOOR TO LAMA'S  CHAMBERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway comes through. He walks as if  in a trance. CAMERA PULLS BACK as he  continues on his way - bearing an expression  of deep absorption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway walks toward an open door  at the end of corridor leading to the  garden. Lovett emerges from one of the  rooms and sees him. He beckons to those  inside and almost immediately they come  out and start toward Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 222. MED. CLOSE SHOT NEAR GARDEN DOOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, just about to exit, when the  others catch up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought you were never coming back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you find out anything about the  porters?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts away from them, but they crowd  around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing all this time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For heaven's sake, Bob, what's the matter  with you? You went out there for the  purpose ofВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George. George - do you mind? I'm sorry,  but I can't talk about it tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shooting toward garden through open  doorway. Conway walks away from the  crowd in f.g., all staring at him, nonplussed.  We see Conway walk through the garden  in b.g. and disappear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares at his brother, off, fearfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a pleasant and peaceful place. Conway  is walking along moodily, drinking in  the pastoral beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks along. He comes to a spot  where a man and a woman are tilling  the soil, and stops to watch them. The  man looks up and, seeing Conway, makes  a friendly bow and doffs his hat. Conway  also bows. The woman curtsies prettily  and smiles. Conway doffs his hat in  acknowledgement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is in a cheerful frame of mind and  continues his walk - CAMERA CONTINUING  WITH HIM. He greets several other people.  Upon seeing him, they also bow and doff  their hats. Conway does likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. SOMEWHERE IN THE VALLEY - DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway is walking along a street in  the valley. It is a quaint thoroughfare,  unlike anything we have ever seen before.  The small, one-story huts along its  very narrow sidewalk are of singularly  varied architecture - giving the impression  of being "homemade." As a result of  this, no two are alike. Only one characteristic  about them is similar - their cleanliness.  Something about the atmosphere is fresh  and wholesome and peaceful. In front  of several of the huts native women  sit - some weaving on a tapestry board,  some nursing babies, some asleep, and  some just sitting. The keynote is contentment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Conway, walking along. As he passes,  the women smile at him in the most friendly  fashion. From inside these homes, soft  and soothing music emanates. At the  end of the street, Conway finally arrives  at a garden spot. The suddenness of  this is startling, too - because of  its beauty. Sighing contentedly, Conway  throws himself at the foot of an overhanging  tree, and leans against the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws his head back, shuts his eyes  - in a restful and contemplative mood.  He remains this way quietly for a few  seconds, when he is attracted by the  singing of a chorus of children's voices.  He glances around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Conway's angle. In the shadow of  a row of overhanging trees which form  an arch, a group of fifteen or twenty  children sing a hymn, or nursery song  - in English. Sondra (the violin girl  of previous scenes) stands in front  of them, a baton in hand, conducting  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles at the sight - and springing  to his feet starts in their direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Sondra and the children, as Conway  saunters into the scene behind her.  He finds himself a comfortable place  under a tree and sits down. The children,  still singing, have seen his approach  and crane their necks curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves her baton and sings with the  children. Then she notices they are  being distracted and casually turns  her head. She is somewhat startled at  seeing Conway, but quickly recovers  her composure, and smiles wanly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To include Sondra, Conway and some of  the children. They finish the song,  and Conway applauds. Sondra curtsies  prettily. She turns to the children.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In unison the twenty children curtsey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway scrambles to his feet and does  an exaggerated bow. Sondra laughs delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, children. We will now singВ–

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lifts her baton and the thin, piping  voices fill the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lights a cigarette and, leaning against  a tree, studies Sondra's face - impressed  by her beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slyly glances backward, and a self-conscious  smile covers her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a child from the ranks breaks and  comes to Sondra, who leans down to listen  to the child - who whispers in her ear.  Sondra, murmuring, "Of course, dear"  and still waving her baton is, for the  moment, uncertain what to do. Then turning  to Conway, holds out the baton to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway snaps out of his reverie and  jumps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the baton from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, taking the child by the hand, she  exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conducting the chorus in all seriousness  - albeit a trifle awkwardly. He turns  his head to watch Sondra, and when he  looks forward again, finds himself off-beat.  To cover his embarrassment, he smiles  foolishly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to the end of the song, but  Conway, whose eyes are searching for  Sondra, is oblivious of this and continues  to conduct mechanically. The children  break into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Sondra as she returns with the  child clinging to her. As she turns  a bend, she looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, children. Now teacher is  going to be very busy this afternoon,  so school's dismissed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The children break into squeals and  race off. THE CAMERA FOLLOWS THEM as  they cross a footbridge, gleefully doff  their clothes and with yelps and cries  leap into a stream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, please. I hope you're not going  to run away this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you'll forgive me forВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hears curious, fluttering music coming  from somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, each time I see you, I hear  that music. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE CAMERA SHOWS PIGEONS swirling overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sondra pulls a miniature flute from  one of her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's these little flutes that I attached  to their tails. See? Come along with  me, and I'll show you how I put them  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of a large coop where pigeons are bred  and raised. The pigeons flutter around,  landing on Sondra and Conway, as she  shows him her collection with pride.  She grabs one pigeon and ties one of  the miniature flutes to its legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, this is how we tie them on.  And by varying the size of the flutes,  I can get any notes I wish. The wind  does the rest. Here's a little fellow  who lost his!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She grabs another pigeon, ties a flute  to its legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You suggested my being brought here,  didn't you? What gave you the idea I'd  fit in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was easy. I read your books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you've read my books. You do more  things! What have my books got to do  with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a man whose life was empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man whose life was empty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know. It was full of this and  full of that. But you were accomplishing  nothing. You were going nowhere, and  you knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, all I saw was a  little boy whistling in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little boy whistling in the dark!?  Do you realize that there is a British  cruiser waiting at Shanghai, smoke pouring  out of its funnels, tugging at its moorings,  waiting to take Mr. Conway back to London?  Do you know that at this minute there  are headlines shrieking all over the  world the news that Conway is missing?  Does that look like a man whose life  is empty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're absolutely right. And I had to  come all the way to a pigeon house in  Shangri-La to find the only other person  in the world who knew it. May I congratulate  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs merrily and shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really only brought you here to show  you my pigeons!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about the pigeons. From  now on, you can put flutes on my tail  and bells on my feet!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns to leave, and he follows,  exiting scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT. SOMEWHERE ON TOP OF A HILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sondra and Conway, walking. This spot  is on top of a hill overlooking the  splendor of the valley below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk along silently for a few seconds,  while Conway studies her face speculatively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are so many questions I'd like  to ask you, I hardly know where to begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll help you. To begin with, you'd  like to know what I'm doing here. Whether  I was born here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I was almost born here. It took  place in that wild country beyond the  pass. My father and mother were in a  party of explorers who got lost and  wandered around for a year. When Chang  found us, only Father and I were alive.  But he was too weak to climb the pass.  He died on the way. I was brought up  here by Father Perrault himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Perrault! I envy you. I talked  to him last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Perrault. Of course I can't quite  get used to this age thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steals a sideways glance at her.  She is greatly amused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you're going to make life very simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they arrive at a scenic overlook.  It is getting toward dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All of it. Father Perrault and his magnificent  history. This place, hidden away from  the rest of the world, with its glorious  concepts, and now you come along and  confuse me entirely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I thought I was to be the  light. But why do I confuse you? Am  I so strange?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the contrary, you're not strange.  And that in itself is confusing. I have  the same idea about Shangri-La. The  sense that I've been here before, that  I belong here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't quite explain it, but everything  is somehow familiar. The very air that  I breathe. The Lamasery, with its feet  rooted in the good earth of this fertile  valley, while its head explores the  eternal. All the beautiful things I  see, these cherry blossoms, you - all  somehow familiar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been kidnapped and brought here  against my will. A crime, a great crime,  yet I accept it amiably, with the same  warm amiability one tolerates only from  a very dear and close friend. Why? Can  you tell me why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps because you've always been a  part of Shangri-La without knowing it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure of it. Just as I'm sure there's  a wish for Shangri-La in everyone's  heart. I have never seen the outside  world. But I understand there are millions  and millions of people who are supposed  to be mean and greedy. Yet I just know  that secretly they are all hoping to  find a garden spot where there is peace  and security, where there's beauty and  comfort, where they wouldn't have to  be mean and greedy. Oh, I just wish  the whole world might come to this valley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it wouldn't be a garden spot for  long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs as they exit scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard is bringing a reluctant Lovett  along on an excursion into the Valley.  They pass friendly natives and farmers  at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know why I associate with you,  Mr. Barnard - or Mr. Chalmers Bryant  - or Mr. Embezzler - or whatever your  name may be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney? Why should I? Never! We have  nothing in common. Hmmpf, Barney! What  effrontery!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this trip to the valley. I can't  imagine why I'd allow you to drag me  down here. Why, we don't know anything  about these people. We're not even armed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're very nice people - except that  they've got horns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard points to sheepherders with  their long horns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett sees his point, starts to chuckle,  but still looks wary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, here! Come on. They won't hurt  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard has encountered some beautiful  native girls, and they have surrounded  him with their hospitality - plying  him with wine and food. Lovett is off  scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, honey, all I want is a glass of  wine! Thanks very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fine. This is swell. No, just  a drink. I've been walking and I'm a  little thirsty, you see? That's all  right. I don't just happen to be very  hungry. Say look, all I asked for was  a glass of water. Look here, I've got  to have some help with this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of Lovett, lagging behind and missing  out on all the fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring Barnard as Lovett comes into  view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Lovey, come here! Lovey, I asked  for a glass of wine and look what I  got. Come on, sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's where you are. I might of  known it. No wonder you couldn't hear  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were asked to have a glass of wine.  Sit down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And be poisoned out here in the open?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For me, won't you please have a glass  of wine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never drink wine in the daytime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as he is poured a glass anyway)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This doesn't obligate me in any way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A merry Lovett has had too much to drink.  Now he is entertaining a group of native  children, who are huddled at his feet.  Other natives watch the entertainment.  Bernard, watching from one side, is  losing patience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: В—then the bears came right into the  bedroom and the little baby bear said,  "Oh, somebody's been sleeping in my  bed." And then the mama bear said, "Oh  dear, somebody's been sleeping in my  bed!" And then the big papa bear, he  roared, "And somebody's been sleeping  in my bed!" Well, you have to admit  the poor little bears were in a quandary!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to sleep in my bed. Come on,  Lovey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were in a quandary, andВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why 'come on' all the time? What's  the matter? Are you going to be a fuss  budget all your life? Here, drink it  up! Aren't you having any fun? Where  was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling this story! I'm telling  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the poor little bears didn't know  what to do, you see, because somebody  had been sleeping in their bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the one who poured him a drink of wineВ—  alluringly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, you call me Lovey, eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at those eyes? There's the devil  in those eyes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Lovett as he enters, unusually  chipper, singing "Here we go gathering  nuts in May . . . " He is in such a  good mood that he improvises the lyrics,  putting Shangri-La in with his la-la-las.  After glancing out the window, Lovett  sits down and pulls out his journal.  He writes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 24TH DAY AT SHANGRI-LA. FEEL SO GOOD  I COULD SOW A WILD OATВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pauses, looks up, opens the compact  box at his side and looks at himself  confidently and admiringly in the mirror.  Returning to his journal, he adds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With George as he disconsolately walks.  He is startled by the sound of Maria's  voice calling him. CAMERA PANS with  him as he crosses to a sheltered spot  where Maria sits on a garden bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You promised to come for tea yesterday.  I waited for so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chagrined to discover he has no cigarettes  left)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't even got any cigarettes left!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please say you will. The days are so  very long and lonely without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll tell me some of the things I  want to know, won't you? You'll tell  me who runs this place. And why we were  kidnapped. And what they're going to  do with us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the moment he starts to speak,  her face clouds. George's voice continues  without interruption.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang's been lying about those porters,  hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following Conway and Sondra as they  stroll peacefully hand in hand amongst  the sculpted shrubbery and rows of flowers.  There is a sudden pealing of bells.  The two of them look off and pause,  their gaze momentarily captured by picturesque  snowcapped peaks in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful! I'm waiting for the bump.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the plane lands at Shangri-La and  wakes us all up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see, it's not a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, sometimes I think that it's  the other that's the dream. The outside  world. Have you never wanted to go there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodness, no. From what you tell me  about it, it certainly doesn't sound  very attractive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not so bad, really. Some phases  are a little sordid, of course. That's  only to be expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the usual reasons. A world full  of people struggling for existence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, everybody naturally wants to make  a place for himself, accumulate a nest  egg, and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, if you keep on asking that,  we're not going to get anywhere. And  don't ask me why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the most annoying word in the English  language. Did you ever hear a child  torture his parent with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother's little darling musn't stick  her fingers in the salad bowl. Why?  Because it isn't lady-like to do that.  Why? Because that's what forks are made  for, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because mother read it in a book somewhere,  and if mother's little darling doesn't  take her fingers out of the salad bowl  this instant, mother's going to wring  her little neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to wring my little neck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway makes a grab for her and she  spurts away. He chases her across part  of the garden, and past the fountain  catches up with her. He reaches to place  his hands around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've thought about it for years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd come. And I knew if you  did - you'd never leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I forgiven for sending for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, when we were on that plane,  I was fascinated by the way its shadow  followed it. That silly shadow racing  along over mountains and valleys, covering  ten times the distance of the plane.  It was always there to greet us with  outstretched arms when we landed. And  I've been thinking that somehow you're  that plane, and I'm that silly shadow.  That all my life I've been rushing up  and down hills, leaping rivers, crashing  over obstacles, never dreaming that  one day that beautiful thing in flight  would land on this earth and into my  arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang is being visited by Lovett, who  has lost his petrified manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing, Mr. Chang. This place is amazing!  And that marble quarry in the valley  is simply magnificent. Oh, I've looked  around. I've seen everything. Your woodworkers  and your cloth-weavers - they all seem  so very, very happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may not know it, Mr. Chang, but  right here you have Utopia.[15]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mean it in that sense. I only  give credit where credit is due.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Er, Mr. Chang, I'm very anxious to have  you realize that I never for a moment  believed that ridiculous kidnapping  story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simply preposterous. Do you know what  I did last night? Last night, Mr. Chang,  I held a sort of a self-inventory. I  said to myself last night, Mr. Chang,  I said, "Lovey"В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lovett! "Mr. Lovett," I said, "you  are an ungrateful fool . . . "

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ungrateful fool . . . !" Those were  my very words to myself last night.  "Here are these people in Shangri-La  doing everything in their power to make  our stay comfortable and happy and I  haven't done one single thing to show  my appreciation."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, what would you like to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Chang, I thought, with your  permission of course, and while I'm  waiting for these porters, I would like  to organize classes for those children  in the valley and teach them something  practical and something useful. Geology.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it? Isn't it! You know I was a  professor for twenty years? - and a  very good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you were. When would you like  to start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway sits on a bench - Barnard leans  over him, showing him a map - a-twitter  with an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see? You get the idea? From this  reservoir here I can pipe in the whole  works. Oh, I'm going to get a great  kick out of this. Of course it's just  to keep my hand in, but with the equipment  we have here, I can put a plumbing system  in for the whole village down there.  Can rig it up in no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize those poor people are  still going to the well for water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of it! In times like these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, what about that gold deal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh - that! That can wait. Nobody's going  to run off with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say, I've got to get busy. I want to  show this whole layout to Chang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long. Don't you take any wooden nickels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears. We hear him whistling,  something joyous. Probably "The Old  Gray Mare Ain't What She Usta Be"В—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he watches Barnard go, pleased at  the metamorphosis that's taking place  in him. Suddenly he sees George and  jumps up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Conway's angle. George has just  made his appearance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George keeps on going and Conway runs  toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway catches up to GeorgeВ—and takes  him by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George - you're behaving like a child.  You haven't opened your mouth in two  weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see that there's anything to  say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And releasing his arm, he leaves Conway  abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a look of deep pain comes into his  face. He stands for several seconds  - looking helplessly - and despairingly  in George's direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chang and Conway playing chess. Conway  leans over the board, a faraway expression  on his face. Chang leans over - moves  a 'man' into position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway looks up - aroused from his reverie.  He glances over the board.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. Not tonight if you don't  mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crosses to a window and glances out.  Chang looks up and sees Maria in doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In doorway. She seems slightly embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. I didn't mean to interrupt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought Mr. Conway's brother was here.  Excuse me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother seems quite fascinated  by her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? She's an attractive young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young? She arrived here in 1888. She  was 20 at the time. She was on her way  to join her betrothed - when her carriers  lost their way in the mountains. The  whole party would have perished but  for meeting some of our people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing! She still doesn't look over  20. When is she likely to grow old in  appearance?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for years. Shangri-La will keep  her youthful indefinitely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave Shangri-La! That's not likely.  You couldn't drive her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean about her appearance. If  she should leave the valley - what would  happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she'd quickly revert in her appearance  to her actual age.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Age is a limit we impose upon ourselves.  You know, each time you Westerners celebrate  your birthday, you build another fence  around your minds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are interrupted by the entrance  of George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there you are! You're just the man  I'm looking for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George comes up to them. He is livid  with rage. He crosses directly to in  front of Chang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fine trick! Smart, aren't you? What  a pack of lies you told us about those  porters! Of course the minute they arrive,  we can make arrangements to leave. If  they take us. But you knew very well  you'd tell them not to!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, my dear boy. You shouldn'tВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been lying to us ever since we  got here! Apparently it's worked with  some people. Perhaps it's because they  lack the courage to do anything about  it. But not me, Chang. You're up against  the wrong man. I'll get out of here,  if I have to blow this fantastic place  into the valley! I'll get outВ—porters  or no porters!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with this threat, he storms out  of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must prevail upon him not to attempt  the journey. He could never get through  that country alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't let him go alone. It's suicide!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He exits abruptly. Chang watches him  depart, deeply upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway sits in the same place before  the Lama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course, your brother is a problem.  It was to be expected.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you'd understand. That's why  I came to you for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must not look to me for help. Your  brother is no longer my problem. He  is now your problem, Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because, my son, I am placing in your  hands the future and destiny of Shangri-La.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For I am going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a pause during which Conway  cannot conceal his amazement at this  simple statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew my work was done when I first  set eyes upon you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway is too awed and impressed to  utter a sound. The High Lama finally  resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have waited for you, my son, for a  long time. I have sat in this room and  seen the faces of newcomers. I have  looked into their eyes and heard their  voices - always in hope that I might  find you . My friend, it is not an arduous  task that I bequeath, for our order  knows only silken bonds. To be gentle  and patient, to care for the riches  of the mind, to preside in wisdom, while  the storm rages without.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think this will come in my time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You, my son, will live through the storm.  You will preserve the fragrance of our  history, and add to it a touch of your  own mind. Beyond that, my vision weakens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I see in the great distance a new  world starting in the ruins - stirring  clumsily - but in hopefulness, seeking  its vast and legendary treasures. And  they will all be here, my son, hidden  behind the mountains in the Valley of  the Blue Moon, preserved as if by a  miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice of the Lama, toward the last,  seems to fade out. Conway, thoroughly  engrossed, half-consciously waits for  it to continue. Following a protracted  silence, he slowly turns toward the  Lama. A breeze blows through the room,  ruffling curtains on the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From whose face the glow has faded.  There is nothing left but a dark-shadowed  mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stares, uncertainly, for a long while,  with a slow realization that the High  Lama is dead. Quite unaware that he  is being moved emotionally, tears well  up in his eyes. While still sitting  this way, unable to stir, he becomes  conscious of activity around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As two servants, unbeckoned, arrive  - only to peer, solemn-faced, at the  Lama. Then, in intervals of seconds,  groups of Lamas, hitherto unseen, enter  softly and silently, and gather around  the High Lama. We hear indistinguishable  murmurs that might or might not be prayers.  Conway is only vaguely aware of their  presence - and after a few moments,  scarcely conscious of what is actuating  his movements, he drifts away from the  murmuring Lamas, and walks in the direction  of the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barnard and Gloria are on their knees  on the floor. Before them they have  spread a large map or chart. Barnard  is enthusiastically out - lining his  plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, honey. We run the pipes through  here, and we connect with the main water  line here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pipes? Where are you going to get pipes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that's a cinch. I'll show them how  to cast pipes out of clay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is as far as they get for George  at this moment barges in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There you are! Barnard, you'd better  get your things together. We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I've just been talking with the  porters. They're going to take us. We've  got clothing, food, everything. Come  on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When are you going to start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this very minute! The porters  are waiting for us on the plateau. And  that Chinaman thought he could stop  me. Come along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll stick around. I'll leave  with the porters on their next trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean you don't want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. You're afraid of going to jail,  eh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, no. You see, I got this plumbing  businessВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! If you insist on being an  idiot, I'm not going to waste time coaxing  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no - you don't want to go yet, honey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure - sure. Don't you worry. I'll take  care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, suit yourself. But just remember  you had your chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he starts out, Lovett enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about you? Do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Home. Away from here. I've got porters  to take us back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 281. CLOSE TWO SHOT - GEORGE AND LOVETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my dear boy, I'm sorry. That's impossible.  Why, I have my classes all started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't care what you've got started.  Do you want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well - no - I think I'd better wait.  Yes, yes. I will. I'll wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovett immediately dismisses George  from his mind and his face brightening,  he starts toward Barnard and Gloria.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Lovett joins the two on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Barney, I've just finished translating  one of the most interesting old tablets  you can imagine. It told me all about  the origin of the Masonic symbols andВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's swell, Lovey. I want to show  you something. Look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, isn't that pretty! What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plumbing. Everything modern. I'm going  to run pipes all through the villageВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all three heads go into a huddle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway stands in front of a window -  his arms extended across - peering out  moodily. He is watching a solemn and  slow-moving procession of torchlight-bearers  - the funeral rites of the High Lama  - accompanied by cermonial music and  drum-beating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting his view of the magisterial  procession.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, as he thoughtfully surveys the  surroundings of which he has just become  master.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George appears in the doorway. He looks  around and espies Conway. For a moment  he stands uncertainly, and finally enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway turns - and seeing him, evinces  no emotion whatsoever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks at him peculiarly. Conway's  behavior is odd in view of their strained  relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you can stop worrying about everything  now, Bob. I've made arrangements to  leave. If you'll let me close that window,  I can talk to you. That noise is driving  me crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said we're getting out of here. Back  to civilization. I made a deal with  the porters. They brought in a load  of books or something, and they're leaving  tomorrow at dawn. They're waiting for  us five miles outside the valley. Come  on, get your things together. Where's  your top coat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? What's going to stop me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't. You've got to stay here  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the matter with you, Bob? You've  been acting strangely ever since we  came here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen you like this. Why can't  we leave? What's stopping us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway combats an impulse to tell him  the whole story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something grand and beautiful, George.  Something I've been searching for all  my life. The answer to the confusion  and bewilderment of a lifetime. I've  found it, George, and I can't leave  it. You mustn't either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're talking about.  You're carrying around a secret that  seems to be eating you up. If you'll  only tell me about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will, George. I want to tell you.  I'll burst with it if I don't. It's  weird and fantastical and sometimes  unbelievable, but so beautiful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, as you know, we were kidnapped  and brought here . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he is speaking, we slowly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway is concluding his story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . . . And that's the whole story, George.  He died as peacefully as the passing  of a cloud's shadow. His last words  to me were, "I place in your hands,  my son, the future and destiny of Shangri-La."  Now you know why I can't leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George listens to him intently, his  face a mask of apprehension. He stares  at his brother for some time and finally  rises and walks around for a few moments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I - I really don't know what to  say. Except that you must be completely  mad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else can I think after a tale like  that? Good heavens, Bob, things like  that don't happen today. We're living  in the twentieth century.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think it's all nonsense, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've been hypnotized by a  lot of loose-brained fanatics. Why,  I wouldn't believe it if I heard it  in an English monastery. Why should  I swallow it here in Tibet? How do you  know the things they told you are true?  Did they show you any proof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew there was a reason I hated this  place. I'd give half my life to fly  over it with a load of bombs just for  what they've done to you. How do you  know the things they told you are true?  Did they show you any proof? All this  talk about the Lamas being hundreds  of years old. How do you know? Did you  see their birth certificates?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it, Bob. A bunch of  decrepit old men sit around and dream  about reforming the world. And you,  Bob Conway - two-feet-on-the-ground  Conway - want to join them. It's horrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all my story meant to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else could it mean to me? It's  obviously a lot of bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'd better go, George. This is  no place for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no place for you, Bob. Think of  what's waiting for you. Do you want  to stay here until you're half dead?  Until your mind starts corroding like  the rest of them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, George. I don't want to talk  about it anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got to talk about it. What about  me? You said they stole that plane to  bring you here. I didn't want to come.  You owe me some responsibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm tired of owing you things. You're  free to go. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's that girl - that girl has twisted  and turnedВ—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway has sunk into a chair. George  kneels before him, pleading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look here, Bob, Ever since I can remember,  you've looked after me. Now I think  you're the one that needs looking after.  I'm your brother, Bob. If there's something  wrong with you, let me help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, I - I don't feel like making  that trip alone, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, you couldn't possibly stay here,  could you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, I may be wrong, I may be a maniac.  But I believe in this, and I'm not going  to lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how much I want to help you,  but this is bigger, stronger if you  like than brotherly love. I'm sorry,  George. I'm staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can't think of anything more  to say. Goodbye, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands warmly. George turns  to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, are you sure of the porters?  About their taking care of you, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes. It's all set. Maria made the  arrangements.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she got to do with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he says this he jumps to his feet.  George is startled by his tone and manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't take her away from here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you can't. Do you know what  will happen to her if she leaves Shangri-La?  She's a fragile thing that can only  live where fragile things are loved.  Take her out of this valley and she'll  fade away like an echo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean - "fade away like an  echo"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring George. He laughs hollowly.  He runs his hand through his hair. He  stares unbelievingly at Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would be funny - if it wasn't so  pathetic. Why, she isn't a day over  twenty!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not wrong. She told me so. Besides,  she wouldn't have to tell me. I'd know  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found out a lot of things last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ashamed of it either. It's probably  one of the few decent things that's  ever happened in this hellish place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So everyone is serenely happy in Shangri-La?  Nobody would ever think of leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all just so much rot! She's pleaded  with me ever since I came here to take  her away from this awful place. She's  cried in my arms for hours, for fear  I'd leave her behind. And what's more,  she's made two trips to the plateau  to bribe the porters - for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it! I don't believe  a word of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. I'll prove it to you! You  believe everything they've told you  - without proof! I'll prove my story!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he speaks he has crossed to door  leading to adjoining room. Conway's  eyes are glued on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few seconds Maria appears in  the doorway and stands there timidly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got some bad news for you, Maria.  My brother and I have decided we can't  take you along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She rushes to George and throws her  arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you promised me! You promised to  take me with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over her shoulder George looks victoriously  at Conway, who cannot believe his ears.  Suddenly Maria wheels on Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all your fault! It was all arranged  until he spoke to you! Why can't you  leave us alone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean to tell me you want to leave  Shangri-La?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll die if I have to stay here another  minute! I've waited a long time for  this chance to go, and you're not going  to stop me now. If I have to, I'll go  alone. It was I who bribed the porters.  If it weren't for me, you'd never get  out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the porters had instructions  from the High Lama not to take anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The High Lama? Who pays any attention  to him? The porters laugh at the High  Lama. All they want to know is how much  gold he will give them. Well, I gave  them more gold. I've been stealing it  for a year. I'd do anything to get out  of this place. To get away from that  High Lama - the one who calls himself  Father Perrault! Why, he's been insane  for years!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead? That's fine. You won't see  me shedding any tears over him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh George, you must take me with you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you afraid to leave? You don't  want to look like an old woman, do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old woman? Chang told you that, didn't  he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought so! He tells everyone I'm  old. He wants them to stay away from  me. He can't stand it when anyone comes  near. He's punished me for every minute  I've spent with George. If it weren't  for him, I would have been out of here  long ago, but he always stops me. Six  months ago, I tried to escape and he  locked me in a dark room. I nearly went  crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me, Mr. Conway, do I look like  an old woman? Is this the skin of an  old woman? Look into my eyes and see  if these are the eyes of an old woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was kidnapped and brought here two  years ago just as we were, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe it! I can't believe  it. She's lying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're lying. You're lying! Every word  you've been saying is a lie! Come on,  say it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has backed her into a corner and  is nearly throttling her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Conway, I'm not lying. What  reason could I have for lying? The chances  are that we'll never come out of that  horrible trip alive, but I'd rather  die out there in a snowstorm and be  buried alive, than to stay here one  more minute now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thoroughly disillusioned, Conway emits  a few cynical chuckles - shakes his  head - stares blankly for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say the porters are waiting for  us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've already asked them. They're afraid  to make the trip. We'll have to send  an expedition back after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway dashes around and collects his  things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Certainly. Come on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start out the door and we . . .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, George and Maria on their way  out of the main building. The funeral  procession continues around them. The  two men walk together, Maria behind.  George is cheerful and buoyant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't be long now before we're in  London. Can't you just see everyone  when we pop out of the blue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway, George and Maria continue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have them breathless when they  hear our story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While he speaks, Conway turns his head  around, looking for a glimpse of Sondra.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he hurries out of the building and  looks out at them from a roof terrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he continues to look back in Sondra's  direction, although he keeps in step  with George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had me worried for a while. I thought  you were gone completely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, George and Maria. George glances  up at Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky thing for me you snapped out of  it, too. You saved my life. I never  could have made it alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you shut up? Must you go on babbling  like an idiot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sondra has come running out to stand  anxiously beside Chang.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shouting, she rushes off and the CAMERA  FOLLOWS HER as she races down a long  flight of stairs, calling out Conway's  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she runs, calling out Conway's name  and weeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Showing Conway, George and Maria - accompanied  by a dozen or more porters - as they  approach the mountain opening where  they first entered Shangri-La.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hesitates at the opening, looks back  one more time. His eyes show confusion  and defeat. George, ahead, calls out  to him to hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she stumbles up the trail to the  opening, minutes behind. The wind howls  on the other side. She cries and weeps,  calling out Conway's name, but he can  no longer be seen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which should be a group of portraits  - showing the group's seemingly impossible  journey back to civilization. These  pictures should be accompanied by music  in the appropriate mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accompanied by the porters, they trudge  laboriously through snow-ridden plains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole caravan are seen in the distance,  clambering up a mountain-side - hoisted  by ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of a vast plain. They  attempt to put up tents, which proves  futile, as a raging snowstorm rips the  canvas from its moorings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The large group are seen lowering themselves  in single file down a ledge alongside  a ravine. The wind howls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mountain pass somewhere with a hailstorm  swiping viciously across their faces.  They edge their way pre-cautiously across  a narrow ledge. Suddenly the girl loses  her bearings - slips - screams - and  is caught by Conway just in time to  save her from falling down the side  of the jagged mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maria has one arm around George and  the other around Conway - limping. She  has her head down. They trudge silently.  The porters are off in the distance,  leaving them behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't stand it. I can't go on anymore!  I've got to rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stumbles and they help her up. George  looks off toward the porters helplessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is this going to go on? I can't  stand it, I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the porters, laughing at their distress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob, can't you get them to wait for  us? They're leaving us farther behind  every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing that would suit them  better than to lose us, but we must  go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't! I can't! You've got to  let me rest! You've got to let me rest!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
