dialogues.text: Of the porters, still laughing. The  lead porter whips out a gun and fires  at them for sport.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are in no danger. The porters are  too far off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Target practice again! One of these  days they're going to hit us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as they keep on aiming at us,  we're safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the porters. They are still laughing,  and now others have drawn out their  guns. Firing off wildly, they trigger  an ominous thunder overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looking up, they see an avalanche beginning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of the avalanche, picking up strength  and fury as it crashes downhill, sweeping  over the porters and crushing them to  death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An immense silence comes over them.  Conway and George can only stare, dazed  and frightened. The only sound is Maria,  sobbing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scene in which Conway carries the  girl on his back. George walks behind.  The wind continues to howl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Staring at the girl's face as it hangs  over Conway's back. Suddenly, his eyes  widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A distorted view of her. Youth and beauty  seem to be vanishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His eyes are glued on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob! Bob! Look at her face, Bob! Her  face! Look at her face!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the backs of the two men, who bend  over Maria. CAMERA DRAWS BACK as they  straighten up. Both stare down aghast  at the girl, whom we do not see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only illumination comes from the  moon. We cannot get a clear view of  her face. But what we see seems to us  to be small, withered and aged. She  is dead. The men stare at her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who watch her, immobile. George looks  despairing. Slowly his head turns toward  the cliff behind him - and his eyes  become alert with an idea. His face  lights up with great determination.  He lets out a piteous howl, and breaks  away, racing out of scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway turns sharply and is horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George stumbling toward the cliff, Conway  chasing him. George, falling head over  heels, rocking on the edge - then plummeting  over, falling down, down into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, at the end of the cliff, peering  starkly downward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Conway soldiers on, alone, through  howling wind and snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Conway, struggling against a cyclonic  wind. He tops a rise, stumbles, falls  over, and rolls down the mountainside,  until finally he comes to a stop, mounded  by snow. Slowly, he begins to rise and  start again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun comes up, Conway emerges  from the whiteness, feeling his way  forward with a walking stick. He walks  with the pain and effort of a blind  man, and just as he manages to cross  a bridge spanning a great chasm, the  bridge collapses. He stumbles on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway, looking haggard and more dead  than alive, stumbles out onto more dry  and level terrain. He collapses to the  ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of Chinese in front of huts.  They look up, see something off and  commence shouting excitedly in their  native tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Similar headlines follow. Newsboys hawk  bulletin editions to milling crowds.  Top-level government dignitaries confer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA MOVES FORWARD passing a series  of desks and clerks until it reaches  a clerk who is opening several cablegrams.  Finally he comes to one which causes  his eyes to pop. Muttering something  under his breath which sounds like "Good  heavens!" - and without taking his eyes  off the cablegram, he rises and starts  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he strides across to the end of the  outer office - to a glass-panelled door  upon which we read "ASSISTANT TO THE  FOREIGN SECRETARY" - through which he  disappears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the clerk enters, full of excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Leaving today for London with Conway  aboard S.S. Manchuria. Conway can tell  nothing of his experiences. Is suffering  from complete loss of memory. Signed,  Gainsford."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONE OF THE OTHERS IN THE ROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, give it to the press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Might as well - all of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll dispatch a convoy to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More newspaper headlines reporting that  Conway has amnesia and other details  of his homeward journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another clerk enters with haste, bearing  another cablegram.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Conway's gone again! Run out! Listen  to this! From Gainsford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Aboard the S.S. Manchuria. Last night  Conway seemed to recover his memory.  Kept talking about Shangri-La, telling  a fantastic story about a place in Tibet.  Insisted upon returning there at once.  Locked him in room but he escaped us  and jumped ship during night at Singapore.  Am leaving ship myself to overtake him,  as fearful of his condition. Wrote down  details of Conway's story about Shangri-La  which I am forwarding. Lord Gainsford."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More newspaper headlines indicating  Gainsford has abandoned his pursuit  of Conway and returned to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. A GRILL ROOM OF A FASHIONABLE CLUB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A scattering of men are present - some  at the bar - others at tables.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From their view. We see Gainsford standing  in the doorway, looking around. He spies  them and starts forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gainsford arrives at the booth. The  men rise with extended hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's good to see you back, Lord  Gainsford! Thought you were never coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you have a drink? Sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Gainsford shakes hands with them,  and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Scotch and soda. I'm parched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, ready and waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes on in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're most eager to know what you've  discovered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All this is said as Gainsford drains  his glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, you see before you a very  weary old man, who has just ended a  chase that lasted nearly ten months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mean to tell me you never caught  up with him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since that night that he jumped off  the ship until two weeks ago, I've been  missing him by inches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was as determined as that to get  back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Determined! Gentlemen, in the whole  course of my life, I have never encountered  anything so grim. During these last  ten months, that man has done the most  astounding things. He learned how to  fly, stole an army plane and got caught,  put into jail, escaped . . . all in  an amazingly short space of time. But  this was only the beginning of his adventures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He begged, cajoled, fought, always pushing  forward to the Tibetan frontier. Everywhere  I went, I heard the most amazing stories  of the man's adventures. Positively  astounding. Until eventually, I trailed  him to the most extreme outpost in Tibet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Favoring the other men, as Gainsford  continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course he had already gone. But his  memory - ah - his memory will live with  those natives for the rest of their  lives. The Man Who Was Not Human, they  called him. They'll never forget the  devil-eyed stranger who six times tried  to go over a mountain pass where no  other human being dared to travel, and  six times was forced back by the severest  storms. They'll never forget the madman  who stole their food and clothing -  whom they locked up in their barracks  - but who fought six of their guards  to escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, their soldiers are still talking  about their pursuit to overtake him,  and shuddering at the memory. He led  them the wildest chase through their  own country, and finally he disappeared  over that very mountain pass that they  themselves dared not travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that, gentlemen, was the last that  any known human being saw of Robert  Conway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By jove, that's what I call fortitude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me something, Gainsford. What do  you think of his talk about Shangri-La?  Do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe it, because I want to believe  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all watch his face, impressed by  his tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I give you a toast. Here  is my hope that Robert Conway will find  his Shangri-La!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is my hope that we all find our  Shangri-La.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all impressed by the sincerity  in his voice - and as their glasses  come together - CAMERA MOVES UP TO A  CLOSEUP OF THEM - and as the music starts  - the picture

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MOVING IN FRONT OF CONWAY - as he walks  forward with a steady step - his head  held high - his eyes sparkling - snow  pelting his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he walks away from the CAMERA, and  we STAY WITH HIM a long time as he approaches  a hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has now ascended to the middle of  the steep hill - his gait unchanged.  THE CAMERA PANS UP to the summit of  the incline - and we see that beyond  it the horizon is filled with a strange  warm light. Conway's figure - in silhouette  - disappears over the hill - bells ring  - and as the music begins to swell[16]
